user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following ignore_sigpipe code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 2.2.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of ignore_sigpipe.
```c
static void
ignore_sigpipe (void)
{
  struct sigaction oldsig;
  struct sigaction sig;

  sig.sa_handler = &catcher;
  sigemptyset (&sig.sa_mask);
#ifdef SA_INTERRUPT
  sig.sa_flags = SA_INTERRUPT;  /* SunOS */
#else
  sig.sa_flags = SA_RESTART;
#endif
  if (0 != sigaction (SIGPIPE, &sig, &oldsig))
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The expression statement '(void) sig;' in the signal handler is an executed no-op whose removal would not change program behaviour. It therefore constitutes dead code (an operation executed but without effect) and violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function ignore_sigpipe:
static void
catcher (int sig)
{
  (void) sig;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  /* do nothing */
}
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report is not correct. The statement “(void) sig;” is an explicit no-op used to mark the parameter as intentionally unused and to suppress compiler warnings; it is a deliberate documentation/diagnostic aid rather than accidental/meaningless code. MISRA Rule 2.2 forbids operations that can be removed without affecting the program behaviour at run-time; removing this cast would not change the program’s run-time behaviour, but it would change compile-time diagnostics and the author’s intent. In practice this idiom is the standard way to document an unused parameter and avoid spurious warnings and is not treated as a defect under MISRA’s intent. Therefore the agent A report (that this is a Rule 2.2 violation) is incorrect.
